name: helium
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a red-orange glow when placed in an electric field
naming: Helios, Greek Titan of the Sun
first isolation by: William Ramsay, Per Teodor Cleve, Abraham Langlet

name: boron
discovered by: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard

name: fluorine
appearance: gas: very pale yellow, liquid: bright yellow, solid: α is opaque, β is transparent
naming: the mineral fluorite, itself named Latin fluo (to flow, in smelting)

name: neon
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in an electric field

name: magnesium
naming: Magnesia, Greece

name: aluminium
naming: alumina (aluminium oxide), itself named mineral alum

name: silicon
naming: Latin silex or silicis, meaning flint

name: phosphorus
appearance: colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black

name: argon
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in an electric field

name: calcium
appearance: dull gray, silver; with a pale yellow tint

name: scandium
naming: Scandinavia

name: chromium
oxidation states comment: (depending on the oxidation state, an acidic, basic, or amphoteric oxide)

name: manganese
oxidation states comment: (acidic, basic or amphoteric; depending on the oxidation state)

name: iron
appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

name: nickel
appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge

name: copper
naming: Cyprus, principal mining place in Roman era (Cyprium)

name: zinc
history comment label: Recognized as a unique metal by

name: gallium
naming: Gallia (Latin for: France), homeland of the discoverer

name: germanium
naming: Germany, homeland of the discoverer

name: selenium
appearance: black, red, and gray (not pictured) allotropes
naming: Selene, Greek goddess of the moon
discovery and first isolation by: Jöns Jakob Berzelius and Johann Gottlieb Gahn

name: bromine
discovery and first isolation by: Antoine Jérôme Balard and Carl Jacob Löwig

name: krypton
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in an electric field

name: strontium
appearance: silvery white metallic; with a pale yellow tint
naming: the mineral strontianite, itself named Strontian, Scotland

name: yttrium
naming: Ytterby (Sweden) and its mineral ytterbite (gadolinite)

name: zirconium
naming: zircon, zargun زرگون meaning "gold-colored"

name: niobium
naming: Niobe in Greek mythology, daughter of Tantalus (tantalum)
history comment label: Recognized as a distinct element by

name: ruthenium
naming: Ruthenia (Latin for: medieval Kyivska Rus region)

name: palladium
naming: asteroid Pallas, itself named Pallas Athena

name: cadmium
discovery and first isolation by: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer

name: indium
discovered by: Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter

name: tellurium
naming: Roman Tellus, deity of the Earth

name: iodine
appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas

name: xenon
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in an electric field
oxidation states comment: (rarely more than 0; a weakly acidic oxide)

name: caesium
naming: Latin caesius, sky blue, for its spectral colours

name: barium
appearance: silvery gray; with a pale yellow tint

name: cerium
naming: dwarf planet Ceres, itself named Roman deity of agriculture Ceres
discovered by: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger

name: promethium
discovered by: Chien Shiung Wu, Emilio Segrè, Hans Bethe
first isolation by: Charles D. Coryell, Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Harold G. Richter

name: samarium
naming: the mineral samarskite (itself named Vassili Samarsky-Bykhovets)

name: europium
appearance: silvery white, with a pale yellow tint; but rarely seen without oxide discoloration
naming: Europe

name: gadolinium
naming: the mineral Gadolinite (itself named Johan Gadolin)

name: terbium
naming: Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

name: erbium
naming: Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

name: thulium
naming: Thule, a mythical region in Scandinavia

name: ytterbium
appearance: silvery white; with a pale yellow tint
naming: Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined

name: lutetium
naming: Lutetia, Latin for: Paris, in the Roman era
discovered by: Carl Auer von Welsbach and Georges Urbain

name: hafnium
naming: Hafnia. Latin for: Copenhagen, where it was discovered
discovery and first isolation by: Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy

name: tantalum
history comment label: Recognized as a distinct element by

name: tungsten
first isolation by: Juan José Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar

name: rhenium
naming: the river Rhine (German: Rhein)
named by: Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, Otto Berg

name: gold
naming: Latin aurum, meaning gold

name: thallium
naming: Greek thallos, green shoot or twig

name: polonium
naming: Polonia, Latin for Poland, homeland of Marie Curie

name: astatine
naming: Greek astatos (αστατος), meaning "unstable"
discovered by: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè

name: radon
discovered by: Ernest Rutherford and Robert B. Owens

name: francium
naming: France, homeland of the discoverer

name: radium
oxidation states comment: (expected to have a strongly basic oxide)

name: actinium
appearance: silvery-white, glowing with an eerie blue light;

name: thorium
naming: Thor, the Norse god of thunder

name: protactinium
discovery and first isolation by: Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring

name: uranium
appearance: silvery gray metallic; corrodes to a spalling black oxide coat in air
naming: planet Uranus, itself named Greek god of the sky Uranus

name: neptunium
naming: planet Neptune, itself named Roman god of the sea Neptune
discovered by: Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson

name: plutonium
appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air
naming: dwarf planet Pluto, itself named classical god of the underworld Pluto
discovered by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan

name: americium
naming: the Americas
discovered by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso

name: curium
appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark
naming: Marie Skłodowska-Curie and Pierre Curie
discovered by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso

name: berkelium
naming: Berkeley, California, where it was discovered

name: californium
naming: California, where it was discovered

name: einsteinium
appearance: silvery; glows blue in the dark
naming: Albert Einstein

name: fermium
naming: Enrico Fermi

name: mendelevium
naming: Dmitri Mendeleev

name: nobelium
naming: Alfred Nobel

name: lawrencium
naming: Ernest Lawrence
discovered by: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Joint Institute for Nuclear Research

name: rutherfordium
naming: Ernest Rutherford
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

name: dubnium
naming: Dubna, Moscow Oblast, Russia, site of Joint Institute for Nuclear Research
discovered by: independently by the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research

name: seaborgium
naming: Glenn T. Seaborg

name: bohrium
naming: Niels Bohr

name: hassium
naming: Hassia, Latin for Hesse, Germany, where it was discovered

name: meitnerium
naming: Lise Meitner

name: darmstadtium
naming: Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered

name: roentgenium
naming: Wilhelm Röntgen

name: copernicium
naming: Nicolaus Copernicus

name: nihonium
naming: Japan (Nihon in Japanese)
discovered by: RIKEN (Japan, first undisputed claim 2004)JINR (Russia) and Livermore (US, first announcement 2003)

name: flerovium
naming: Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions (itself named Georgy Flyorov)
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR) and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL)

name: moscovium
naming: Moscow region
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

name: livermorium
naming: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, itself named partly Livermore, California
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

name: tennessine
naming: Tennessee region
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Vanderbilt University and Oak Ridge National Laboratory

name: oganesson
naming: Yuri Oganessian
discovered by: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
